lg.l: WollewardL.18.1: The ornamental capital of six lines is in blue ink with red flourishes. A small guide letter <w> is in the left margin. and wete-shoed Â· went I forth after
As a reccheles renke Â· Ã¾at of no wo reccheth
And Èede forth lyke a lorel Â· al my lyf-tyme
Tyl I w..ex wery of Ã¾e worlde Â· and wylned eft to slepe
And lened me to a lenten Â· and longe tyme I slepte
And of crystes passioun and penaunce Â· Ã¾e peple Ã¾at of-rauÈte
RestedL.18.7: LR alone read Rested; most other manuscripts have Reste. me Ã¾ere and rutte faste Â· tyl ramis palmarum
Of gerlis & of gloria laus Â· gretly me dremed
And how osanna by orgonye Â· olde folke songen
Â¶ One semblable to Ã¾e samaritan Â· & some-del to Piers Ã¾e plowman
Barfote on an asse bakke Â· botelees cam pryke
Wyth-oute spores other spere Â· spakliche he loked
As is Ã¾e kynde of a knyÈte Â· Ã¾at cometh to be dubbed
To geten hemL.18.14: L alone reads hem; other B manuscripts have hym. gylte spores Â· or galoches ycouped
Â¶ Ãanne was faith in a fenestre Â· and cryde a fili dauid
As doth an Heraude of armes Â· whan aunturos cometh to iustes
Olde iuwes of ierusalem Â· for ioye Ã¾ei songen

lg.l: Â¶ Ãanne I frayned at faith Â· what al Ã¾at fare be-ment

And fecche Ã¾at Ã¾e fende claymeth Â· Piers fruit Ã¾e plowman

Ãis Ihesus of his gentrice Â· wole iuste in piers armes
In his helme & in his haberioun Â· humana natura
Ãat cryst be nouÈt biknowe here Â· for consumatus deus
In Piers paltok Ã¾e plowman Â· Ã¾is priker shal ryde
For no dynte shal hym dere Â· as in deitate patris
Who shal iuste with Ihesus quod I iuwes or scribes
Â¶ Nay quod he Ã¾e foule fende Â· and fals dome & deth
Deth seith he shal fordo Â· and adown brynge
Al Ã¾at lyueth or loketh Â· in londe or in watere
Lyf seyth Ã¾at he liktheL.18.32: LRF alone read likthe; most other B manuscripts have lieÃ¾. Â· and leyth his lif to wedde
Ãat for al Ã¾at deth can do Â· with-in Ã¾re dayes
To walke and fecche fro Ã¾e fende Â· piers fruite Ã¾e plowman
And legge it Ã¾ere hym lyketh Â· and lucifer bynde
And forbete and adown brynge bale deth for euere

Tho put hym forth a piloure Â· bifor pilat & seyde

To fordone it on o day Â· and in thre dayes after
Edefye it eft newe Â· here he stant Ã¾at seyde it
And Èit maken it as moche Â· in al manere poyntes
Bothe as longe and as large Â· bi loft & by grounde

And bigan of kene thorne Â· a gerelande to make
And sette it sore on his hed Â· and seyde in envye
Aue rabby quod Ã¾at Ribaude Â· and Ã¾rew redes at hym
Nailled hym with Ã¾re nailles Â· naked on Ã¾e Rode
And poysoun on a pole Â· Ã¾ei put vp to his lippes
And bede hym drynke his deth yuel Â· his dayes were ydone

Ãe lorde of lyf & of liÈte Â· Ã¾o leyed his eyen togideres
Ãe daye for drede with-drowe Â· and derke bicam Ã¾e sonne
Ãe wal wagged and clef and al Ã¾e worlde quaued

And tolde whi Ã¾at tempest Â· so longe tyme dured
For a bitter bataille Â· Ã¾e ded bodye sayde
Lyf and deth in Ã¾is derknesse Â· her one fordoth her other

Er sondey aboute sonne rysynge Â· & sank with Ã¾at til erthe

For he was knyÈte & kynges sone Â· kynde forÈaf Ã¾at tyme

marginalia.note: L.18.81-85: The musical pun nota in the right margin appears to apply to the entire line group.

lg.l: Â¶ Ac Ã¾ere cam forth a knyÈte Â· with a kene spere ygrounde
HiÈte longeus as Ã¾e lettre telleth Â· and longe had lore his siÈte
Bifor pilat & other peple Â· in Ã¾e place he houed
Maugre his many tethe Â· he was made Ã¾at tyme
To take Ã¾e spere in his honde Â· & iusten with ihesus
For alle Ã¾ei were vnhardy Â· Ã¾at houed on hors or stode
To touche hym or to taste hym Â· or take hym down of Rode
But Ã¾is blynde bacheler Ã¾anne Â· bar hym Ã¾orugh Ã¾e herte
Ãe blode spronge down by Ã¾e spere Â· & vnspered Ã¾e kniÈtes eyen
Ãanne fel Ã¾e knyÈte vpon knees Â· and cryed hym mercy
AÈeyne my wille it was lorde Â· to wownde Èow so sore
He seighed & sayde Â· sore it me athynketh
For Ã¾e dede Ã¾at I haue done Â· I do me in Èowre grace
Haue on me reuth riÈtful ihesu Â· & riÈt with Ã¾at he wept
Â¶ Thanne gan faith felly Â· Ã¾e fals iuwes dispise
Called hem caytyues Â· acursed for euere
For Ã¾is foule vyleynye Â· veniaunce to Èow alle
To do Ã¾e blynde bete hym ybounde Â· it was a boyes conseille
Cursed caytyue Â· kniÈthod was it neuere
To mysdo a ded body Â· by day or by nyÈte
Ãe gree Èit hath he geten Â· for al his grete wounde
Â¶ For Èowre champioun chiualer chief knyÈt of Èow alle

For be Ã¾is derkenesse ydo Â· his deth worth avenged
And Èe lordeynes han ylost Â· for lyf shal haue Ã¾e maistrye
And Èowre Fraunchise Ã¾at fre was Â· fallen is in thraldome
And Èe cherles & Èowre children Â· chieue shal Èe neure
Ne haue lordship in londe Â· ne no londe tylye
But al bareyne be Â· & vsurye vsen
Which is lyf Ã¾at owre lorde Â· in alle lawes acurseth
Now Èowre good dayes ar done Â· as Danyel prophecyed

Whan cryst cam Â· her kyngdom Â· Ã¾e croune shuldeshulde [cesse]L.18.112: Most beta witnesses read cesse after shulde, whereas alpha manuscripts have lese. The corrector's marginal <+> indicates he noticed the omission.

Out of Ã¾e west coste Â· a wenche as me thouÈte
Cam walkynge in Ã¾e wey Â· to helle-ward she loked

A ful benygne buirde Â· and boxome of speche

Euene out of Ã¾e est Â· and westward she loked
A ful comely creature Â· treuth she hiÈte

Of Ã¾e dyne & of Ã¾e derknesse Â· and how Ã¾e daye rowed

Ich haue ferly of Ã¾is fare Â· in feith seyde treuth
And am wendyng to wyte Â· what Ã¾is wonder meneth

A mayden Ã¾at hatte marye Â· and moder with-out felyng
Of any kynnes creature Â· conceyued Ã¾orw speche
And grace of Ã¾e holygoste Â· wex grete with childe

And Ã¾at my tale be trewe Â· I take god to witnesse

Where pees cometh playinge Â· in pacience yclothed
Loue hath coueyted hir longe Â· leue I none other
But he sent hir some lettre what Ã¾is liÈte bymeneth

Ãat ouer-houeth helle Ã¾us Â· she[he]L.18.175: The "correction" â if indeed this is what has occurred, since only crowding suggests that the <s> is added as an afterthought â is itself quite possibly an error. Alpha supplies the correctly alliterating pronoun he, indicating the accuracy of the scribe's exemplar. Stress and alliteration on vs would be unmetrical. vs shal telle

RiÈtwisnesse hir reuerenced Â· for her riche clothyng
And preyed pees to telle hir Â· to what place she wolde
And in her gay garnementz Â· whom she grete Ã¾ouÈte
Â¶ My wille is to wende quod she Â· and welcome hem alle

Adam & Eue & other moo in helle Â·
Moyses & many mo Â· mercy shal haue

For ihesus iusted wel Â· ioye bygynneth dawe

Where he were god or goddes sone Â· he gaf me shorte answere

For iuwes hateden hym Â· and han done hym to deth
